text: We'll hear argument next in No. 97-1625, California Dental Association v. Federal Trade Commission.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Would you just remind me, counsel?
If the Court please, I've searched the record and I come to the conclusion that the Kansas City Area Hospital Association was not a 501(c)(3).
Do you recognize that there might be some 501(c)(6) organizations that would fit the definition of carries on business for the profit of its members?
Oh, yes, Your Honor.
So, you're distinguishing among 501(c)... you're not saying all nonprofits are out.
That is correct, Your Honor.
And so, now you're going to tell us why, say, the Dental Association is different from the Real Estate Board.
Yes.
Well, how about a trade organization that's there to promote, say, eggs?

--Well, Your Honor, in the Seventh Circuit case involving egg nutrition, they made a... the trial court... and it was affirmed in the Seventh Circuit... made a specific finding that they were organized for the profit of the Egg Commission.
Well, I guess there are some benefits, though, for the dentists to belong to the Dental Association: better insurance vehicles and other benefits that the organization may provide to its members.
--Well--
Do you say that the organization provides no benefits to its members?

--Oh, no, I wouldn't... I wouldn't say that because the... the membership dues for the tripartite membership in dentistry is over 1,000 dollars, and I think they get their... their membership benefits.
Wasn't there a finding someplace that the value of the membership to each dentist was worth... I don't know 20,000 dollars or something?
That was... that was not a finding, Your Honor.
But I read section 44 to say an organization which is organized to carry on business for its own profit or for the profit of its members.
Well, if the Court please, that turns on the definition of profit.
Yes.
And the Community Blood Bank case said that that's the excess of revenue over expenses, either paid or contemplated to be paid.
No, but it says, or the profit of its members.
Well--
--in the business of... the profession of dentistry.

--If the Court... well, no, Your Honor, not in the... not in the sense of the profit, the way that term is defined in the Blood Bank case and in a legion of cases that define the term profit, Your Honor.
Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
